messages.content:
I'm currently building zkApp, which will manage several merkle trees. However, I bumped into the problem of concurrent Merkle Tree updates.

One way to deal with this is to use Action/Reducer.

I found a thread https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1169006012502659212, but it still leaves me with some questions:

1) Can we reduce actions only within 5 blocks? Actions that are older than 5 blocks will be ignored?
2) If more than 32 actions are added, the contract is dead, or it will fail to add transactions until the actions is reduced?

Besides that question, maybe someone could help me with the following

3) Are there any examples of updating multiple Merkle trees with action/reducers?
4) May be there is a different approach to this problem that you can suggest? (Some vector commitments or something like that.)

embeds.title: Discord - Group Chat That’s All Fun & Games
embeds.description: Discord is great for playing games and chilling with friends, or even building a worldwide community. Customize your own space to talk, play, and hang out.

messages.content: you’d be reinventing Protokit 😅
@Alekasndr Ivlev have you considered using experimental offchain state? It does concurrent Merkle tree updates with actions for you under the hood
You can also treat the offchain state implementation as an example, but it's pretty optimized and generic, and therefore complex
Havent seen it before. Sounds interesting. We were also offered solution for it in proposal thread(https://forums.minaprotocol.com/t/zknoid-l1-lottery/6269/20) by @zkKirol. Is it the same solution?

embeds.title: ZkNoid:L1 Lottery
embeds.description: Hey,  yes, you would be able to call the reduce before the queue is full but that’s not what I’ve said about locking the contract. There is a high likelihood of users trying to dispatch as you’re reducing.  The solution that will work would require making snapshots of actions, reversing them and iterating from the latest. (this will take 2 stora...

messages.content: Just search offchainstate on our docs

@gregor What will happen if we try to dispatch action and reduce actions in the same block(with 2 transactions)? Will reduce trasaction fail? For example, if users call our transaction every block, will we compete with them to run reduce, ot not?
No that's not a problem
Reducing won't include the actions from the current block

How is it working? I saw something like actionState.requireEquals(proof.initialState), so I expect transactions from this block to change actionState. In this case this check will fail.  Is actionState updates only in the end of block? Or we can use some historic values of actionState?
Yes we can use historic values - the current action state as well as the states at the end of 4 previous blocks (skipping blocks which had no actions)
Action state has to match one of those 5 values

Got it. 

What are known limitations of offchain storge? Is ther some cases the should avoid, that can break the contract? 

By the way, I saw, that currentry accumulator changes are not supported. Can we somehow adapt offchainstorage for out app to support it, or is it not trivial task?
Not trivial imo, better to use a custom reducer + IndexedMerkleMap in that case
@Alekasndr Ivlev check this discussion for limitations https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1254496178570137731/1254496178570137731
Ok. Thanks

Hey @Alekasndr Ivlev and @gregor !  I am trying to find this in the code.  I came across this chunk in Mina: https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/blob/47b45a20ab7f24974a90374aa441b42787e4f72b/src/lib/mina_base/zkapp_precondition.ml#L734

Does this mean if I write a precondition on actionState for a contract is `xyz`, Mina will _always_ check for `xyz` in the last 5 blocks?  Or is there a special way that reducers do this from o1js?

embeds.title: mina/src/lib/mina_base/zkapp_precondition.ml at 47b45a20ab7f24974a9...
embeds.description: Mina is a cryptocurrency protocol with a constant size blockchain, improving scaling while maintaining decentralization and security. - MinaProtocol/mina

messages.content:
Hi,  

I haven't dug too deep, but from my experience, there are two ways to check the action state:  

1) In this case, a precondition is created for the latest `actionState`:  
   ```  
  this.account.actionState.getAndRequireEquals().assertEquals(reduceProof.publicOutput.finalState);  
   ```  
2) In this case, preconditions are generated for any of the last five states:  
   ```  
   this.account.actionState.requireEquals(reduceProof.publicOutput.finalState);  
   ```  

Hope this helps.

Interesting.  Maybe we should update the behavior for `getAndRequireEquals` for action states, if the protocol behavior is to check if it's in a list.  Maybe what's happening there is that bringing the action state into typescript, we only access the latest, and create an assertion that's more strict than the protocol is?

So if you use `getAndRequireEquals`, and there are actions you didn't know about that get included in the last block, your transaction will fail, but if you use `requireEquals`, you can safely use an actions hash from 2 or 3 blocks ago, even if actions are emitted since?

getAndRequireEquals will just use the getAccount query to get the account, like all our "get" methods. Then it puts that action state into the precondition.

I would've expected getAccount to get accounts from the latest *finished* block (but it might be worth checking that, and how the node even determines the latest block). If that's the case, additional actions won't be able to change it.

But the latest block might be more sensitive to forks than 2-3 blocks in the past.

Yes! What you put in the action state precondition can match any of the last five distinct action states. Note that this could cover much more than 5 blocks since the list is only updated for blocks that had any actions for the account.
Reducer doesn't do anything special, it just uses the precondition
I wish we had a spec for Mina...

Matthew shared this message internally confirming with more details.  I'll add it here in case anyone searches for this again:

Precondition check is triggered [here](https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/blob/47b45a20ab7f24974a90374aa441b42787e4f72b/src/lib/transaction_logic/zkapp_command_logic.ml#L1268C10-L1268C36). In turn, this calls into [here](https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/blob/47b45a20ab7f24974a90374aa441b42787e4f72b/src/lib/transaction_logic/mina_transaction_logic.ml#L1583), which forwards it onto here. In turn, that checks the entire list of conditions, of which the relevant one is this [one](https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/blob/47b45a20ab7f24974a90374aa441b42787e4f72b/src/lib/mina_base/zkapp_precondition.ml#L736).
https://github.com/bkase/MIPs/blob/main/MIPS/mip-zkapps.md#actions

messages.content: This mentions that there are 5 actions states stored, but doesn't explain how the precondition is evaluated.  "action_state : the root of the actions merkle list for this account". This is what's written in the preconditions section, but it's not clear.  Can I set a precondition on just one of the states?  Any one of them, or only the most recent one?  Can I set a precondition that matches any, all, some, or none of them?  Basically the only way to find out is to dig through the ocaml code and see what it does...
There is a link to actions in the beginning of this doc that is broken now; maybe it was explained there, as I remember that it was clear for me after reading the docs
